Summary I am an enthusiastic technical professional seeking full-time permanent or contract opportunities in quality engineering and continuous improvement project management. 
 
 
Professional Specialties: 
- Certified Quality Engineer with more than 15 years of experience teaching and applying statistical methods, including design of experiments (DOE) 
- Experienced project manager highly recognized for ability to consistently meet goals by building and driving high performance teams in both the corporate and non-profit sectors 
- 11 years of expertise in statistical process control standards and application 
- Adept at use of model-based problem solving techniques to determine root cause and develop appropriate closed loop corrective action 
 
Personal Pursuits: 
- Society of Women Engineers 
- The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, Team In Training

• Market research Experience Vice President Crosly & Associates 2013  – Present (2 years) Southern California Incorporated in 1945, Crosly & Associates is the premier executive search firm in the analytics space. The firm has been built by analytical talent -- for analytical talent. Our recruiters hold Masters or PhDs in quantitative disciplines, and have all worked out in industry. We utilize our strong educational background and our "in the trenches" industry accomplishments (including hands-on analytics, SAS programming and statistical modeling experience) in every one of our search engagements. These hands-on experiences in the analytics work space afford us the unique ability to very effectively ‘talk shop’ with the most seasoned analytics candidates and client executives at all levels. Summary Dr. Karl Pazdernik is a Postdoctoral Researcher in the Department of Statistics at North Carolina State University, funded through the Consortium for Nonproliferation Enabling Technology (www.cnec.ncsu.edu). He received his PhD in statistics from Iowa State University in 2013. 
 
Prior to coming to NCSU, Dr. Pazdernik was a Senior Statistician at Intel Corporation (2013-2015) working as a statistical consultant and spent time at NCAR (the National Center for Atmospheric Research) working on spatial statistics methods. During his time at Iowa State University, he was both a Graduate Research and Teaching Assistant. As a research assistant, Dr. Pazdernik fit mixed models to fMRI data and was a member of the Agriculture Experiment Station Consulting Group. As a teaching assistant, he spent two semesters running a lab and grading for a general introductory statistics course, four semesters teaching Stat 101 - Principles of Statistics, and four semesters teaching an introductory statistics course for engineers. 
 
His research interests include Spatial Statistics, Statistical Computing, Information Fusion, Sports Statistics, and Data Mining. Dr. Karl Pazdernik is a Postdoctoral Researcher in the Department of Statistics at North Carolina State University, funded through the Consortium for Nonproliferation Enabling Technology (www.cnec.ncsu.edu). He received his PhD in statistics from Iowa State University in 2013. 
 
Prior to coming to NCSU, Dr. Pazdernik was a Senior Statistician at Intel Corporation (2013-2015) working as a statistical consultant and spent time at NCAR (the National Center for Atmospheric Research) working on spatial statistics methods. During his time at Iowa State University, he was both a Graduate Research and Teaching Assistant. As a research assistant, Dr. Pazdernik fit mixed models to fMRI data and was a member of the Agriculture Experiment Station Consulting Group. As a teaching assistant, he spent two semesters running a lab and grading for a general introductory statistics course, four semesters teaching Stat 101 - Principles of Statistics, and four semesters teaching an introductory statistics course for engineers. 
 
His research interests include Spatial Statistics, Statistical Computing, Information Fusion, Sports Statistics, and Data Mining. Experience Postdoctoral Researcher NC State University June 2015  – Present (3 months) Raleigh-Durham, North Carolina Area My postdoctoral fellowship is funded through the Consortium for Nonproliferation Enabling Technology (www.cnec.ncsu.edu). This work will focus on the development of statistical methods and tools to combine and analyze data from multiple sources with the goal of identifying signatures and guiding decisions about data collection.
